text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section I have three words for you hot
buttery biscuit
sound good I'm going to show you how to
make them the first thing you need to
know about biscuits is that they are
dead simple you can get the ingredients
anywhere and then you can just whip them
up the secret to Southern biscuits which
are the lightest most ethereal biscuits
in the world white lily flour it has a
low protein content sadly I can't get it
in the North so instead I compensate by
using a combination of regular
all-purpose flour and a little cake
flour and then together it brings the
protein content to the right level but
if you don't have cake flour regular
all-purpose is just fine then I'm going
to add a little bit of salt some baking
powder and some sugar use a whisk to mix
it because this introduces some air into
the flour mixture which helps lighten it
and then just whisk until everything is
evenly distributed you can go to
nytimes.com slash dining for the exact
recipe some biscuit recipes use a
combination of butter and shortening
some use all shortening some use all
butter I'm using all butter because I
like the flavor the best make sure your
butter is chilled I cut this up earlier
and then I put it back in the fridge so
that it would get extra cold I'm using a
pastry cutter to mix the butter into the
flour yes if you want to use your food
processor you can but I like to go
old-school here it gives me more control
I can really see what I'm doing by using
the pastry cutter what I'm looking for
is a uniform texture you want to stop
when it's evenly distributed and the
butter is the size of peas this is
looking good now I'm going to add cold
buttermilk I'm gonna gently mix it in
with a spatula until it just comes
together at this point where it's mostly
mixed but not entirely I'm just gonna
dump it out on the counter and finish it
there first sprinkle the counter with
just a little bit of flour very lightly
see just press it together with your
hands you want to be as gentle as
possible here you don't want to overwork
the dough you're not looking for smooth
you see how this has a bunch of cracks
in it but it mostly holds together
that's when you stop it your best bet is
to pat this out with your fingers you
could use a rolling pin but then you
risk overworking the dough Pat it down
to three quarters of an inch thickness
you don't need a perfect circle but you
do need an even thickness and if it
starts to get sticky teeny bit of flour
right on top now when you cut out your
biscuits and this is important always
dip the biscuit cutter in a little flour
first so it doesn't stick and then
here's something equally important do
not twist don't put it in there and go
because what you're doing is gluing the
sides together and it's going to impede
the rise another thing to remember is to
cut out your biscuits as close together
as possible I like to line my baking
sheet with parchment paper you can also
just butter it if you want fluffy
biscuits that aren't that Brown place
them close together if you want a lot of
browning around the edges separate them
do not reroll the scraps if you re roll
the scraps you're gonna get hockey pucks
instead of biscuits instead just push
them together gently these are not gonna
be the prettiest biscuits but they
should taste pretty good and then okay
I'm gonna get one more biscuit out of
this I'm not even going to cut it I'm
just smashing it together in a round and
i'm gonna plop it on the baking sheet so
these are the fancy ones for your guests
and these are the sloppy ones for your
family they'll all taste just as good
and just brush the tops with a little
melted butter you could also use milk or
cream on top but I say more butter is
just better so now I'm gonna bake these
at 425 until they're puffed and golden
brown about 15 to 20 minutes
so here you go hot buttered biscuits
these are the gorgeous ones these are
the ugly ducklings still just as
delicious I have three more words for
you yum yum
